title: 4,500 stranded Thomas Cook holidaymakers to arrive home on Friday
text:
EasyJet reveals it is looking to buy out parts of collapsed airline and tour operator

A further 4,500 holidaymakers stranded abroad by the collapse of Thomas Cook will arrive home on Friday, as easyJet reveals it is looking at buying some of the airline and tour operators’ assets.

The Civil Aviation Authority said about 90% of the 150,000 holidaymakers abroad at the time of Thomas Cook’s collapse have now been brought home to the UK.

Separately, Johan Lundgren, the chief executive of easyJet, has said that the company is looking at Thomas Cook’s assets.

“Of course, like all airlines and tour operators, we will look at what might be of interest to us from the Thomas Cook network,” he told German newspaper Die Welt. “But there is no decision yet.”

Before its collapse last month, Thomas Cook received seven non-binding offers for parts of its business – its airline operation, tour operator and Nordic business – which were all rejected by its board and lenders.

The last flights of the authority’s Operation Matterhorn, the largest peacetime repatriation plan in UK history involving 140 aircraft and 800 flights, will bring the remaining 14,000 holidaymakers home by Sunday. Twenty six flights will operate on Friday.

“Around 90% of Thomas Cook passengers have now been repatriated and we will continue to work around the clock to support the final passengers’ return to the UK,” said Richard Moriarty, chief executive of the CAA.

The CAA said 94% of people have flown back on the original days of their cancelled Thomas Cook flight.

Moriarty said some holidays booked through Thomas Cook travel agents remained valid because they were booked with tour operators outside the Thomas Cook Group.

“Check your booking documents and, if you still aren’t sure if your holiday is valid, confirm with your nearest Abta-approved travel agent,” he said.
description: EasyJet reveals it is considering buying out parts of defunct airline and tour operator
